explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 and Class 8 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#3455 Cresol (solid))

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 599degC (ICSC, 2000)

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available - melting point: 30degC (ICSC, 2000), test temperature: 140degC

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Corrosivity to metals remains uncertain, though classified as "corrosive substances" (as the classification based on UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods includes "skin corrosivity") (UN#3455 Cresol (solid)).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 121 mg/kg (EHC 168 (1995)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the animal LD50 (dermal route) value of 620mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 620mg/kg and 890mg/kg (EHC 168 (1995)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "irreversible destruction of skin tissues" (EHC 168 (1995)) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on animal eye irritation tests (IUCLID (2000)): "Moderate to severe eye irritation" and "permanent corneal opacity and vascularization"

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Insufficient data available, though the results of guinea pig skin sensitization tests based on the Maximization method are negative.

carcinogenicity.rationale: The results of in vitro studies suggest induction of chromosome aberration (SIDS (1998)), while those of multi-generation mutagenicity studies (1), germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (2), somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (3), germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo (4,5) are all negative. The results of germ cell multi-generation mutagenicity tests in vivo (dominant lethal tests) are also negative (ATSDR (1992)).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category C by EPA (1991).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Abnormal estrous cycle and lateral ventricle dilation are observed in offspring at dose levels toxic to parent animals.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "irritation to the larynx and nose, narrowing and dry nostrils" (MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 1 (2002)). The substance is thus considered "irritating" to the respiratory tract.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, heart, liver, kidney, respiratory system)
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system, heart, liver, kidney, respiratory system)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "a decrease in locomotor activity, adverse effects on body weight gain, pulmonary edema and hemorrhage, degeneration of the myocardium, liver, kidneys and central nervous system (nerve cells and glia cells), upper respiratory tract inflammation, pulmonary edema, perivascular fibrosis" (CERI Hazard Data 97-9 (i) (1998)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours LC50=5mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (EHC168 (1995) and others.).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the 20 days decomposition rate: 86% (SIDS, 1998)) and the bio-accumulation was low (BCF=10.7 (SIDS, 1998)), it was claasified into Not classified.
